Separating from the nature of language, one should know all dharmas as they really are. Having done so, there is not a single dharma that can give rise to false thoughts. One should take things as they are, and not think that this is a thing and that is its suchness. One should only practice its meaning.
Having practiced the ultimate truth, one should know and see all dharmas as they really are, without compare, and be equal to all. Observing equality, one attains the supreme equanimity.
Relying on the supreme equanimity, one should skillfully penetrate all sÅ«tras, treatises, and skillful means.
One should never retreat from all suffering and difficulty. One's mind should be firm and one's body free from exhaustion.
One should skillfully attain great mindfulness and not be arrogant about one's skillful means.
One should teach sentient beings the Dharma without holding anything back, and one's mind should not be timid about skillful means.
They are capable and never regress, able to don the great firm armor.

In this way, the suffering of birth and death increases, and in this way, one is able to increase the unsurpassed bodhi. In this way, merit increases, and in this way, arrogance and shame decrease. In this way, wisdom becomes brighter, and in this way, one fully understands disputes, transgressions, and afflictions. Knowing this, one lets go.
In this way, merit increases, and in this way, one further conceals it and does not let others know, not for the sake of gain.
In this way, bodhisattvas have immeasurable benefits, in accord with the path of bodhi, all relying on that wisdom.
Therefore, bodhisattvas who have attained, are attaining, and will attain bodhi, all rely on that wisdom, not on anything inferior or superior.

In this way, the bodhisattva who is free from falsehood has immeasurable benefits such as these. He is able to accomplish the unsurpassed Buddha Dharma and benefit sentient beings with the teachings of the Three Vehicles. This is called right progress.
Having progressed correctly, he is himself far removed from craving and attachment to his body and wealth.
Having studied to be free from craving, he further teaches sentient beings to be free from greed and attachment.

He gives up his body and wealth, and with an impartial mind provides what is needed to sentient beings. He skillfully controls his faculties and studies the discipline of body and speech. By nature he does not enjoy evil and is truly kind and virtuous, and he endures others' transgressions and various evil deeds.
Having studied and practiced patience, his anger and resentment gradually diminish and he does not trouble or oppress others.

He diligently studies all the fields of knowledge, skillfully resolves the doubts and difficulties of sentient beings and benefits them, and also embraces the causes for attaining omniscience himself. He concentrates his mind and abides in meditative absorption, purifies the four immeasurables and roams in the five supernatural powers, and studies all skillful means in all activities. He is never tired of establishing or abandoning all skillful means.
They are able to skillfully contemplate the foremost truth and skillfully cultivate the foremost Mahayana, and will never wish for or seek nirvana in this world.

In this way, they are ultimately perfect in equality, and serve and make offerings to the greatly virtuous, and give rise to a mind of great compassion for evil beings, removing evil conduct to the best of their ability.

For those who dislike and harm them, they give rise to a mind of kindness, and according to their ability and tolerance, without flattery or pretense, they bring about beneficial happiness, causing their grudges and evil to naturally disappear.
For those who benefit them, they treat them equally or with increase, know their kindness and repay their kindness, and cause them to be fully satisfied in seeking according to the Dharma.
If they themselves lack the power, even if they are not requested, they must make expedient means, their minds not resting, causing them to know that they have nothing to spare.
This is called the bodhisattva's abandonment of falsehood and reliance on the foremost true wisdom of equality and expedient means.
How does one know that all dharmas are apart from verbal expression?

These nominally designated intrinsic characteristics of dharmas, namely form, feeling, perception, impulse, consciousness, up to nirvana, should be known as nominally designated without intrinsic nature, and also not apart from them there is a place of verbal activity and verbal object.
Thus, there is no intrinsic nature, as it is spoken by language, and also not completely non-existent;
Thus, this non-existence is also not completely non-existent.
How does it exist?
This existence, which is free from both the existence of reality and the denial of reality, is called the ultimate intrinsic nature, free from all conceptual thoughts and the domain of wisdom.
If a dharma exists as it is spoken, it should have intrinsic nature. If so, one dharma and one thing should have many intrinsic natures.
Why is it so?
It is because one dharma and one thing have many names and designations.

It is also not that multiple names have a definite nature, nor that a single name has its own nature while other names are without self-nature. Therefore, the designation of provisional names, whether multiple or single, is all without self-nature.

Furthermore, if dharmas from form up to nirvÄá¹‡a have self-nature according to their names, then there must be a dharma first and then a name is established according to one's intention. When there is no name, that dharma should be without self-nature.
If it is without self-nature, then there is no basis for establishing a name.
This meaning is not so.
It is also not so that there is a dharma without a name.
If the dharma's own nature is form, and then the name and speech are used to grasp that form,
if that is so, then apart from the name there should be the establishment of form, and sentient beings should naturally know it is form without depending on the name to know it.
But sentient beings do not know form without a name. Therefore, it is known that all dharmas are apart from the self-nature of speech. Form up to nirvÄá¹‡a is also like this.
Furthermore, there are two kinds of people who destroy the true Dharma of the Buddha:

First, if one establishes false names and speaks of self-nature and self-characteristics in regard to form and other dharmas, form and other matters, and becomes attached to false dharmas through false conceptualization;

Second, in regard to the basis of establishing false names and the support of false names, one slanders and destroys the ineffable self-nature, saying that the ultimate truth is completely nonexistent.

As for the faults of establishing false characteristics of dharmas as explained above, it means that in regard to form and other dharmas, form and other matters, one falsely takes what is not real to be real. Because of these faults, one destroys the true Dharma.

Moreover, in regard to form and other dharmas, form and other matters, one slanders and destroys the limited scope of causes and conditions, saying that they are completely nonexistent, and thus destroys the true Dharma.
Now, I will explain how one slanders and says that form and other dharmas, and form and other matters, have no reality and no false names in regard to the limited scope of causes and conditions.
Both of these are incorrect.
It is possible to say that the aggregates such as form and so forth are called a person,ğŸ”½...
One should not be like a person who speaks of nothing.

Just as a person who speaks of nothing, and just as a person who does not speak of nothing, in the same way, the establishment of provisional names for dharmas such as form within the scope of causes and conditions is not the establishment of provisional names for nothing. This is how it should be.
If it were only provisional names with nothing, then there would be no basis and also no provisional names. This is not correct.

When such a person hears the difficult-to-understand sÅ«tras of the Great Vehicle that accord with the meaning of profound emptiness, they do not understand the true teachings at all, and with incorrect contemplation and false discrimination, using expedient wisdom they make such statements:
All of this is provisional names, without any reality. Contemplating in this way is correct contemplation.
Such people have nothing at all as the basis for provisional names, and provisional names also do not exist.
Since provisional names do not exist, the reality of provisional names also does not exist.
Those who slander both reality and provisional names are said to be completely nihilistic.
Those who speak thus of non-existence should not be spoken to or associated with by those of wisdom and pure conduct, as they will destroy themselves and the world.
Therefore, the World-Honored One spoke of this matter:
It is better to hold the view of self than to wrongly grasp emptiness.
Why is this?

Those who hold the view of self do not slander all that is to be known and the precepts they know, and because of this view, they do not fall into evil paths, do not destroy others' faith and joy in liberation from suffering, do not create obstacles, are able to establish the true and correct Dharma, and do not become lax in the precepts and rules.

Those who wrongly grasp emptiness slander all that is to be known and the precepts they know, and because of this, they fall into evil paths, destroy others' faith and joy in liberation from suffering, create obstacles, become lax in the precepts, and slander the true Dharma, thus destroying the Buddha's teachings.
What is meant by wrongly grasping emptiness?
If Å›ramaá¹‡as and brÄhmans say that everything is completely empty, this is called wrongly grasping emptiness.
Why is this?
If it is said that this emptiness lacks that nature, or if it is said that this emptiness has this nature, this meaning should be so.
If everything lacks nature, where and of what is it empty?
It should also not be said that this is precisely this emptiness.
What is meant by skillfully grasping emptiness?
If this thing lacks that thing, it is called emptiness;
To know as it is that this thing is not empty is called knowing as it is without error.
Emptiness refers to the nominal designation of form and so forth, which lacks intrinsic nature;
Yet form and so forth have a remainder, namely the causal factors and conditions of the nominal designation of form and so forth.

To know both as they are in reality means to know the extent of phenomena and the extent of nominal designations as they are in reality. One does not establish what is not real, nor does one slander what is real. One neither increases nor decreases, neither elevates nor deprecates. To know the nature free from verbal expression as it is in reality and as it is in suchness is called skillfully grasping emptiness, which is to be known by right wisdom.
I have fully contemplated and compiled, speaking of all dharmas as being apart from the nature of verbal expression.
I will now speak of all dharmas as being apart from the nature of verbal expression, as I have heard from the Buddha.
As the Buddha, the World-Honored One, has said in the sutras, there is a verse that shows:
Just as various names are used to speak of various dharmas,
Herein there is no such thing, this dharma is like this.
This verse shows the establishment of provisional names.
Dharmas such as form and so forth are proclaimed using names such as form and so forth, circulating the teachings, speaking of form up to nirvana.
The provisional names such as form and so forth have no self-nature of form and so forth, and the dharmas such as form and so forth also have no other self-nature.
This provisional name of form and so forth, all dharmas are apart from verbal expression, the meaning is non-existent, this is called the ultimate nature of dharmas.
As the World-Honored One said in the chapter on meaning:
The Sage is not attached to the worldly collection of words,
Who can be attached to what is not attached? One does not give rise to views of seeing and hearing attachment.
This verse shows that the nominal designation of form and so forth is the establishment of the affairs of form and so forth. This is called the worldly collection of verbal expressions.
This nominal designation and those affairs do not have their own nature.
Why is it so?
Because there is no view of establishment and denial.
The absence of that inverted view is called the view of non-attachment.
In this way, who can give rise to the view of attachment to form and so forth, whether establishing or denigrating?
The correct contemplation of the object of non-attachment is called the view;
Listening to the verbal expressions of what is to be known is called hearing. Therefore, one does not give rise to defiled attachment in seeing and hearing.
Completely abandoning all in those conditions is called not giving rise to the view of attachment in seeing and hearing.

Furthermore, the Buddha told the monk MahÄ KÄtyÄyana, A monk does not cultivate meditation relying on earth, water, fire, or wind, on space, consciousness, nothingness, or neither perception nor non-perception, on this world or the other world, on the sun or the moon, on seeing, hearing, knowing, or cognizing, on seeking, attaining, awakening, or contemplation. He does not rely on any of these to cultivate meditation.
How does he not rely on earth up to not relying on awakening and contemplation to cultivate meditation?
KÄtyÄyana!
If the earth and the concept of earth are eliminated, up to all and the concept of all are eliminated.
A monk who cultivates meditation like this is said to cultivate meditation without relying on earth, up to cultivating meditation without relying on all.
A monk who cultivates meditation like this, the Åšakra DevÄnÄm-Indra, the MahÄ BrahmÄ, and the BrahmÄ gods all come to pay homage and praise him in verse, saying:ğŸ”½Homage to the supreme person!
Homage to the one above all persons!
Now I do not know you, on what do you rely to meditate?
This sutra shows that the names of earth and so forth are many things. The establishment of names such as earth and so forth is called the concept of earth.

Moreover, this concept of earth and so forth, regarding those named things, if one establishes their nature or if they are all destroyed, it is called the concept that destroys the ultimate truth and accepts slander.

If one removes those concepts, it is called cutting them off, it is called abandoning them. One should know that this is called hearing from the TathÄgata, the teacher of the ultimate truth, that all dharmas are devoid of the nature of verbal expression.
As for all dharmas being devoid of the nature of verbal expression, what is the use of all verbal expressions?
If there are no words, one cannot speak to others about the dharma that is devoid of verbal expression.
Since there is no speaking, there is also no hearing.

Since there is no speaking and no hearing, one who is able to know that all dharmas are devoid of the nature of verbal expression does not exist. Therefore, there should be verbal expression to enable others to hear and know.
The foolish and ignorant do not know this as it really is. For this reason, they give rise to eight kinds of false thoughts and produce three things, increasing the world of sentient beings' vessels.
First, the false thought of self-nature;
second, the false thought of discrimination;
third, the false thought of grasping and accumulating;
fourth, the false thought of self;
fifth, the false thought of what belongs to self;
sixth, the false thought of recollection;
seventh, the false thought of non-recollection;
eighth, the false thought of both.
These are called the eight false thoughts.
What are the three things that arise?

First, the false thought of self-nature, the false thought of discrimination, and the false thought of grasping and accumulating - these three false thoughts are the places of false thoughts and deceptions, the objects of deceptive clinging. Based on this, false names such as form arise.
If those objects and places are grasped and increased by names, thoughts, and language, immeasurable deceptions will always occur without cease.

Second, the two delusions of self and mine and self-possession are the view of the aggregates, which is the root of all views and the root of pride. The pride of thinking I am can give rise to all kinds of pride.
Third, the delusions of recollection, non-recollection, and their mutual contradiction give rise to greed, anger, and delusion as appropriate.
These are called the eight kinds of delusions that give rise to three kinds of things.

Namely, the false things of the realm of delusions, the things of the view of the aggregates and pride of thinking I am, and the things of greed, anger, and delusion. Based on the false things of delusions, the view of the aggregates and pride of thinking I am arise. Based on the view of the aggregates and pride of thinking I am, greed, anger, and delusion arise.
These three kinds of things are the accumulation and burning of all worlds.
What is self-nature delusion?
If one has the delusion of saying this is form regarding nominally existent things such as form, this is called self-nature delusion.
What is discriminating delusion?

Regarding these nominally existent things such as form, to say this is form and that is not form, this is visible and that is not visible, this is resistant and that is not resistant, this is contaminated and that is uncontaminated, this is conditioned and that is unconditioned, and so on, making innumerable distinctions, to make discriminations of distinctions in the place of self-nature conceptualization, this is called discrimination of distinctions.
What is the conceptualization of appropriation and accumulation?

Regarding nominally existent things such as form, self, person, life, sentient being, conceptualizing them as worldly conventions, accumulating many dharmas for the benefit of form and so on, accumulating and appropriating them, giving rise to houses, armies, forests, groves, food, drink, clothing, carriages, and so on.
Conceptualizing them as worldly conventions for the benefit of accumulation, this is called the conceptualization of appropriation and accumulation.
What is the conceptualization of mine and I?

If those things are contaminated aggregates of feeling, they are long-accumulated habits of attachment to self and what belongs to self. Therefore, there is no place of acceptance, but one practices in one's own views. Due to this cause and condition, false thoughts arise contrary to reality. This is called the false thought of self and what belongs to self.
What is the false thought of recollection?
It is a false thought that takes as its object what is pure, wonderful, and delightful.
What is the false thought of non-recollection?
It is a false thought that takes as its object what is impure and not delightful.
What is the false thought that takes as its object both recollection and non-recollection?
It is a false thought that takes as its object both what is pure and impure, and what is delightful and not delightful.
In brief, there are two things: false thoughts and the basis of false thoughts, and the objects of false thoughts.

These two things, both from the beginningless beginning, each cause each other. Past conceptualization gives rise to present conceptualization and conditioned things. Present conceptualized conditioned things give rise to present conceptualized conditioned things. Because they do not know present conceptualized things, they again give rise to future conceptualized conditioned things.
Once conditioned things arise, they will definitely again give rise to those conceptualized conditioned things.
How do we know conceptualization?
There are four kinds of seeking and four kinds of thorough understanding.
What are the four kinds of seeking?
First, seeking names;
second, seeking things;
third, seeking the establishment of intrinsic natures;
fourth, seeking the establishment of distinctions.
Seeking names means bodhisattvas contemplate names within the scope of names when seeking names.
Thus, they contemplate things within the scope of things when seeking things.
They contemplate the establishment of intrinsic natures within the scope of the establishment of intrinsic natures when seeking the establishment of intrinsic natures.
They contemplate the establishment of distinctions within the scope of the establishment of distinctions when seeking the establishment of distinctions.
Whether observing names and things separately or observing them combined, it is the observation of the establishment of self-nature and the establishment of distinctions.
What are the four kinds of thorough understanding?

Thorough understanding of seeking according to names, thorough understanding of seeking according to things, thorough understanding of seeking according to the establishment of self-nature, and thorough understanding of seeking according to the establishment of distinctions.
What is thorough understanding of seeking according to names?

Bodhisattvas seek the scope of names according to names. Thoroughly understanding such names, they know that these names are established for this thing, for conceptualization, for views, and for dissemination.
For things with false names such as form, if the names form, etc. were not established, no one would be able to know things such as form.
If one does not know, one does not contemplate things.
Those who do not contemplate do not speak.
Thoroughly understanding in this way is called thorough understanding of seeking according to names.
What is thorough understanding of seeking according to things?

Bodhisattvas, regarding phenomena, seek to observe the nominal phenomena such as form, etc., and all verbal phenomena apart from verbal expression. This is called the second kind of seeking the truth according to phenomena.
What is seeking the truth according to the nature of designation?
Bodhisattvas, regarding the nominal phenomena such as form, etc., seek the nature of designation and the extent of the nature of designation.

Observing the characteristics of the nature of these phenomena as they really are, like an illusion, a reflection, an echo, a mirage, the moon in the water, a dream, or a magical creation, observing the characteristics of the nature as devoid of reality, this is called the third kind of seeking the truth according to the nature of designation, which is the profound meaning of seeking the truth as it really is.
What is seeking the truth according to the nature of differentiation?

Bodhisattvas, regarding the nature of differentiation in the designation of differentiation, seek the non-duality of the nominal phenomena such as form, etc., in the nature of designation of differentiation.
Contemplate that phenomena are neither existent nor nonexistent by nature. Verbal expressions are ungraspable by nature, and also not nonexistent.
Apart from the nature of verbal expressions, the established nature is neither form, because it is the ultimate truth.
Also not formless, because form exists in the conventional truth.

Just as there is existence and nonexistence, form and non-form, in this way all phenomena that can be seen and cannot be seen are differentiated and established. One should know that they are all like this.
To know the non-dual meaning of these differentiated establishments as they really are is called knowing as it really is through seeking according to differentiated establishments.
If those eight kinds of wrong thoughts give rise to three kinds of things for foolish ordinary beings, they increase the world.

Those who are not fully endowed with the four kinds of knowledge as they really are will give rise to the afflictions of wrong thoughts. Because they give rise to afflictions, they experience birth and death. Because they experience birth and death, they increase the many sufferings such as birth, old age, sickness, death, and so forth that follow birth and death.
If bodhisattvas rely on the four kinds of knowledge as they really are, they will know the eight kinds of wrong thoughts in the present world.
Having known it in the present world, false things in the future dependent conditions will no longer arise.
Those things that do not arise, those false thoughts in future conditions will not be born.
Thus, when those things and those false thoughts are extinguished, all falsehoods will also be extinguished.

When falsehoods are extinguished, bodhisattvas will quickly attain the great vehicle's great parinirvÄá¹‡a, and in the present world they will be able to attain the wondrous and great spiritual powers of the great beings, perfect all the powers of great mastery, namely the spiritual powers of various transformations and various changes, and with omniscience be unobstructed in all things, freely living or passing away as they wish.
Attaining such immeasurable spiritual powers, they are called the most supreme and unsurpassed of all beings.
Such bodhisattvas of great mastery accomplish five kinds of supreme and wondrous merits:
First, they attain the samÄdhi of the foremost pure mind, which is quiescent yet not extinguished in all afflictions;
Second, the pure knowledge and insight into all the scriptures increases without decrease;
Third, for the sake of sentient beings, dwelling in saá¹ƒsÄra without weariness;
Fourth, skillfully entering the purport of the TathÄgata's teachings;
Fifth, skillfully understanding the Great Vehicle without receiving it from others.
These five kinds of merits are the five kinds of functions:

First, the supreme bliss of the present world, the arising of the skillful means of opening awareness and the skillful means of body and mind, all fatigue is eliminated, this is the function of the merit of mental tranquility.
Second, accomplishing all the Buddha's teachings, this is the function of the merit of the pure knowledge and insight into all the scriptures.
Third, accomplishing sentient beings, this is the function of the merit of not being weary in saá¹ƒsÄra.

Fourth, teaching and transforming sentient beings, being able to resolve doubts that have arisen and those that have not yet arisen, upholding the true Dharma and enabling it to endure for a long time, those who have similar dharmas that can extinguish the true Dharma, skillfully knowing and skillfully speaking, enabling them to be eliminated, this is the merit and virtue of skillfully entering the purport of the TathÄgata's teachings.

Fifth, subduing all non-Buddhist doctrines and heterodox arguments, firmly and diligently not extinguishing the correct vow, this is the merit and virtue of well understanding the Great Vehicle and not receiving it from others.

Thus, all that bodhisattvas do is subsumed within these five meritorious and virtuous activities, namely, undefiled joy, maturing the Buddha's teachings, accomplishing sentient beings, upholding the true Dharma, subduing heterodox arguments, ardently practicing, and the correct vow being unshakable.
As for those four kinds of true meanings, the first and second are inferior, the third is middling, and the fourth is superior.
Chapter on Powers, Bodhisattva Grounds, Chapter on Skillful Means, Chapter on Powers, Chapter 5 What are the powers?
In brief, there are three kinds:
First, the buddhas and bodhisattvas attain the samÄdhi of mastery, and based on the samÄdhi of mastery, they are able to do anything they wish. This is called the power of the sages.
Second, the Dharma has great fruits and great benefits. This is called the power of the Dharma.

Third, the buddhas and bodhisattvas have previously accomplished great merit and skillful means, and the buddhas and bodhisattvas have innate extraordinary and unprecedented qualities. This is called the power of innate qualities.
Furthermore, these three kinds of power can be distinguished by type. The buddhas and bodhisattvas have five kinds of power:
First, the power of spiritual abilities;
Second, the power of the Dharma;
Third, the power of innate qualities;
Fourth, the power shared with all Å›rÄvakas and pratyekabuddhas;
Fifth, the power not shared [with others].
As for spiritual abilities, they refer to the six spiritual abilities:
First, spiritual powers;
Second, divine hearing;
Third, knowledge of others' minds;
Fourth, knowledge of past lives;
Fifth, knowledge of birth and death;
Sixth, realizing the destruction of defilements.
This is called the power of spiritual penetrations.
The power of the Dharma refers to the six perfections:

The perfection of generosity, the perfection of morality, the perfection of patience, the perfection of diligence, the perfection of meditation, and the perfection of wisdom. These are called the power of the Dharma. Since these dharmas have what is capable, they are called the power of the Dharma.
What are the bases of spiritual power?
In brief, there are two kinds:
First, transformation;
Second, creation.
If classified by type, there are innumerable [types].
What is the spiritual power of transformation?

Classified by type, it refers to shaking, burning, filling, manifesting, transforming into different parts, going and coming, large and small, forms entering the body, going in accordance with what is similar, hiding and appearing freely, obstructing the spiritual powers of others, bestowing eloquence, bestowing mindfulness, bestowing joy, emitting great light, and so forth. These are called the spiritual power of transformation.

Shaking means that when Buddhas and Bodhisattvas attain the samÄdhi of mastery, they can perform deeds to shake temples, cities, palaces, villages, houses, hells, animal realms, hungry ghost realms, human realms, heavenly realms, the four continents, the world system of a thousand worlds, the world system of two thousand worlds, the world system of a thousand times a thousand worlds, the world system of a thousand times a thousand times a thousand worlds, up to countless world systems of a thousand times a thousand times a thousand worlds, all of which are shaken.

Blazing means emitting fire from the upper body and water from the lower body, or emitting water from the upper body and fire from the lower body, entering the samÄdhi of fire and the whole body is in full blaze, manifesting various colors such as blue, yellow, red, white, and crystal.
Filling means emitting light from the body to fill a house, up to filling countless world systems of a thousand times a thousand times a thousand worlds.

Manifestation means sitting peacefully, appearing as the assembly of Å›ramaá¹‡as, the assembly of brÄhmans, the assembly of Å›rÄvakas, the assembly of pratyekabuddhas, the assembly of bodhisattvas, the assembly of devas, nÄgas, yaká¹£as, gandharvas, asuras, garuá¸as, kiá¹ƒnaras, mahoragas, humans, non-humans, and so forth.
The buddhas and bodhisattvas manifest themselves in all realms, from the lower realms up to the human and heavenly realms.

Even in the buddha-lands of the ten directions, as numerous as the sands of the Ganges River, it is the same. Even in buddha-lands beyond immeasurable buddha-lands, as numerous as the sands of the Ganges River, they can manifest their names and lands, and they can also manifest even more than that, according to their wishes.
Transforming into different categories means transforming earth into water, which becomes true water, not anything else;
transforming into fire and wind is also like this.
Just as with earth, water, fire, and wind, it is not anything else.
Just as with the four elements, so it is with form, smell, taste, and touch.

Grass, trees, mud, and soil transform into food, drink, clothing, necklaces, fragrant flowers, fragrant ointments, and various adornments. Sand, gravel, tiles, and stones transform into various jewels. The Snow Mountain King and all the mountains transform into the color of gold. All of this is truly so, nothing else.

Beings with good complexion transform into those with bad complexion, and beings with bad complexion transform into those with good complexion. Sometimes those with good or bad complexion transform into those with an average complexion, and sometimes those with an average complexion transform into those with good or bad complexion.

Like those with good or bad complexion, those with complete limbs and those with incomplete limbs, those who are fat and those who are thin, and so forth, all have their own characteristics. One can transform their complexion freely and without obstruction, not transforming everything as one wishes.

As for coming and going, there is no obstruction in stone walls. One can go up to the Brahma world and even to the Akaniá¹£á¹­ha Heaven. Whether coming or going, one has complete freedom, pervading the innumerable and boundless trichiliocosm in the ten directions.
Whether it is a transformed body or a body of coarse four elements, coming or going is also like this.
If there is a thought of far or near, one can instantly go back and forth.
As for large and small, one can make the Himalayas like a single atom, and make a single atom like the king of the Himalayas.

As for making forms enter one's body, all the Å›ramaá¹‡as, brÄhmaá¹‡as, and the great assembly, as well as the villages, cities, grasses, trees, forests, and all the mountains and earth, all forms are contained within the body. At that time, the great assembly each sees themselves entering the bodhisattva's body.
As for going to similar places, if one goes to an assembly of ká¹£atriyas, one will have the same appearance, body size, height, and voice as them, and speak the same language.
One will speak the same as them.

For what they cannot do, one will explain it for them, extensively expounding the true Dharma to delight them, and then disappear in front of them. One will not let them know who came or went, whether it was a god or a human.

Emitting great light means that through the spiritual power of Buddhas and Bodhisattvas, light is emitted that pervades the immeasurable worlds in the ten directions. The suffering of hell beings is alleviated, and up to the gods, dragons, yakshas, gandharvas, asuras, garudas, kinnaras, mahoragas, humans, non-humans, and others, they see the light come to the Buddha's place, and the assemblies of Bodhisattvas from other worlds all gather.
In brief, the immeasurable Buddhas in the worlds of the ten directions emit immeasurable light, benefiting and bringing peace and joy to immeasurable beings.
This is called the spiritual power of transformation.
If classified by type, there are immeasurable and countless [types], except for transforming one's own nature into something else. Therefore, it is called the spiritual power of transformation.
What is the spiritual power of transformation?
In brief, it means creating things that did not exist before, being able to transform and manifest according to one's wishes. This is called the spiritual power of transformation.
This transformation has many types, either transforming the body or transforming speech.

As for the transformation body, it may resemble one's own body or not, it may resemble another's body or not. Moreover, one's own body and another's body may be similar or dissimilar. One transforms to be similar to the sense faculties and their bases, but one does not create real sense faculties.

Moreover, one transforms to create similar objects, namely, food, drink, various treasures, and various implements that include color, smell, taste, and tactile objects, all according to one's wishes.

Moreover, one's own body may be similar, either transforming into one body or into innumerable bodies, such as those of devas, dragons, yaká¹£as, gandharvas, asuras, garuá¸as, kiá¹ƒnaras, mahoragas, humans, non-humans, and so forth, with various appearances. Humans, animals, hungry ghosts, hell beings, Å›rÄvakas, pratyekabuddhas, bodhisattvas, and tathÄgatasâ€”such appearances, according to their respective circumstances, one is able to transform into bodies similar to oneself, or if different from one's own body, they are called dissimilar.

If one creates a body unlike that deity, it is called a transformation of another's body unlike itself.
It is the same up to the body of a Buddha.

As for innumerable bodies, it means that Buddhas and Bodhisattvas simultaneously create various forms in innumerable and countless worlds in the ten directions, benefiting innumerable beings in the ten directions.

Although the Buddhas and Bodhisattvas go to other places, the transformations remain as before. Sometimes they temporarily manifest like an illusion for beings, or they create food, drink, clothing, vehicles, gold, silver, pearls, lapis lazuli, crystal, shells, and jade. All these transformations are like the norm and can be used as usual. This is called a transformed body.

As for transformed speech, it is endowed with wonderful sounds and extensive sounds. It may arise from one's own body, from another's body, or from nowhere. It may expound the true Dharma or give instructions according to circumstances.

Wonderful sound refers to the Buddha and Bodhisattvas transforming their speech, with a voice as deep and far-reaching as thunder, or as subtle as the sound of the kalaviá¹…ka bird, with a delightful sound, a pleasing sound, a lovable sound, widely transforming into immeasurable sounds, with correct and easy-to-understand eloquence, which is delightful to hear and inexhaustible.

Vast sound refers to the Buddha and Bodhisattvas transforming their great sound, causing devas, nÄgas, yaká¹£as, gandharvas, asuras, garuá¸as, kiá¹ƒnaras, mahoragas, humans, non-humans, Å›rÄvakas, pratyekabuddhas, great bodhisattvas, and immeasurable assemblies, even up to one yojana inside and outside, to hear it everywhere, whether in a small chiliocosm, a medium chiliocosm, a trichiliocosm, or even in the immeasurable worlds of the ten directions, they all hear it everywhere. For the sake of sentient beings, they use their own voice to expound immeasurable teachings in a single sound.
The second is that which arises from others, such as transforming into the speech of others to expound the Dharma for people, to eliminate their negligence.
The third is that which arises from nowhere, such as the sound of transformation in space, like human speech.
The fourth is expounding the true Dharma, for deluded beings expounding the true Dharma, enabling them to attain understanding.

The fifth is admonishing according to circumstances, even though they are not doubtful, they attain a mind of faith and joy but are negligent, enabling them to give rise to shame and remorse and be diligent.
There are many such [types], but in brief there are three types:
Transforming the body, transforming sound, and transforming objects, this is called the supernormal power of transformation.
If each is individually distinguished, there are innumerable [types].
Thus the two types of supernormal powers of buddhas and bodhisattvas can accomplish two things:
First, in order to cause beings to give rise to faith and joy, the supernormal powers manifest transformations to enable them to enter the Buddha's teachings;
Second, to gather suffering beings and bring them peace and benefit.
What is the supernormal knowledge of past lives?
It means that Buddhas and Bodhisattvas know their own past lives, such as This sentient being was my name in the past, as explained in detail in the sutras.
Knowing the past lives of others is also like knowing one's own. One can cause others to know one's own past lives.
Those sentient beings who were formerly associated with oneself can also be caused to recall their own past lives.

After those sentient beings know that they were formerly associated with the Bodhisattva, they also know that other sentient beings were associated with them, and they can also cause those other sentient beings to know each other's past names and various causes and conditions.
This should be explained in detail here.
From the present and the past,
up to immeasurable and innumerable eons ago,
the order of events, large and small, is known in every moment. This is called the supernormal knowledge of past lives of Buddhas and Bodhisattvas.

Bodhisattvas know for themselves the practices of past lives and the bodhisattva path, which were unprecedented events. What is the supernormal knowledge of birth and death?

Up to transformed appearances and the subtle appearances of the heavens, all are seen.

From the highest heaven of the form realm down to the AvÄ«ci Hell, and in the worlds of the ten directions, they do not use expedient means to observe each individual characteristic. Fourth, by these causes and conditions, wherever one is born, one obtains great wealth, a great lineage, and great retinue. This is called the four merits and virtues of giving, without remainder and unsurpassed.
What are the four matters of upholding precepts?
First, receiving the precepts of body and speech, which counteracts breaking precepts.
Second, accomplishing the requisites for attaining enlightenment.

Third, upholding pure precepts, using the same benefits to gather and perfect sentient beings, being far removed from the fear of the enemy of breaking precepts, sleeping and waking in constant peace, benefiting oneself.
Moreover, one who upholds precepts has no regrets in the mind and always obtains joy, up to the mind being concentrated on all matters of benefiting oneself. This is called gathering oneself.
Universally bestowing all fearlessnesses upon sentient beings is called gathering others.
Fourth, by these causes and conditions, one is reborn in the heavens upon death. This is called the four powers of upholding precepts, without remainder or supreme.
What are the four matters of patience?
First, cultivating patience to counteract impatience.
Second, accomplishing the requisites for enlightenment.
Third, with firm patience, benefiting oneself and others, and subsuming and accomplishing sentient beings, crossing over great terrors. This is called subsuming oneself and others.

Fourth, by these causes and conditions, in future lives there will be no enemies or separation. Since there is no separation, there is also no worry or suffering. What are the four matters of vigor?
First, vigor to counteract laziness.
Second, accomplishing the requisites for enlightenment.

Third, relying on diligent effort, one subsumes and takes in sentient beings to be trained through shared benefits. Diligently abiding in the abandonment of evil dharmas, one increases in merit and virtue, rejoicing and delighted, benefiting oneself. This is called self-subsumption.
Diligent in cultivating goodness, one does not frighten sentient beings with body or speech. When sentient beings see this, they also delight in diligent effort. This is called subsuming others.

Fourth, through these causes and conditions, one is able to accomplish the extraordinary meritorious deeds of a great person in the future. This is called the power of the four meritorious dharmas of diligent effort, without remainder, unsurpassed.
What are the four things of meditative concentration?
First, meditative concentration counteracts afflictions. The afflictions of verbal distraction, joy, and conceptualization of form are all extinguished.
Second, it perfects the requisites for enlightenment.

Third, relying on meditative concentration, one subsumes and takes in sentient beings to be trained through shared benefits. Abiding in the bliss of the present dharma, one subsumes oneself. The mind is tranquil and free from craving. This is called self-subsumption.
Not being angry or irritated towards sentient beings is called embracing others.

Fourth, due to these causes and conditions, in future lives one is born in the heavens, with pure wisdom and pure spiritual powers. This is called the four kinds of merits and powers of dhyÄna concentration, without remainder and unsurpassed.

Universally for the sake of sentient beings, one skillfully preaches the Dharma, enabling them to attain the bliss of this world and the next. This is called embracing others.

The power of dignified behavior and innate strength means always lying on the right side like a lion king.
